description: From Middle English schyne, from Old English scinu, from Proto-West Germanic *skinu, from Proto-Germanic *skin≈ç. Cognate with West Frisian skine, Dutch scheen, German Schiene.

entries.meaning: The front part of the leg below the knee; the front edge of the shin bone:  Shinbone on  Wikipedia.Wikipedia

verbs.description: shin (third-person singular simple present shins, present participle shinning, simple past and past participle shinned)

entries.meaning: (Britain, as "shin up") To climb a mast, tree, rope, or the like, by embracing it alternately with the arms and legs, without help of steps, spurs, or the like.
(US, slang) To run about borrowing money hastily and temporarily, as when trying to make a payment.
examples: The Senator was shinning around, to get gold for the rascally bank-rags which he was obliged to take.

entries.meaning: The twenty-first letter of many Semitic alphabets/abjads (Phoenician, Aramaic, Hebrew, Syriac, Arabic and others):  Shin (letter) on  Wikipedia.Wikipedia
